content:
Bipolar disorder: Symptoms diagnosis and treatment

Bipolar disorder is a mental disorder with many complex symptoms. People with the disease will often have changes in their psychological state, in addition to having a negative impact on the patient's health, affecting their activities and life.

What is bipolar disorder?
Bipolar disorder is a mental disorder marked by erratic changes in mood. The patient may fall into a state of overstimulation and hyperactivity, but then fall into a state of depression. Bipolar disorder is also known as manic-depressive disorder. Psychological instability and unusual up and down moods can appear several times a year, or several times a week. People with the disease will have difficulty working and maintaining relationships.
Bipolar disorder is characterized by episodes or periods of illness that alternate periodically in the form of manic or depressive episodes. The disorder causes unusual changes in mood, energy, activity levels, and the ability to perform daily tasks.
Having bipolar disorder pushes people into two different psychological states.

Symptoms of bipolar disorder
The telltale signs of bipolar disorder are considered by experts to be somewhat similar to many other psychological diseases. Therefore, finding symptoms to distinguish bipolar disorder and depression, especially depression of bipolar disorder, is very necessary. Bipolar disorder will have two different phases: the manic phase and the depressive phase. (first)
1. Symptoms of manic phase
They may feel excited, impulsive, excited, and energetic. Then the patient will have changes such as:
Hyperactivity, excess energy, no need for sleep, little sleep Eager to talk, talk fast, talk a lot Positive, simple thinking, reckless decisions without calculating money or work; Hyperactivity, excess energy, no need for sleep, little sleep; Talking excitedly, talking quickly, talking a lot; Optimistic, simple thinking, reckless decisions without calculating money or work
The patient feels happy, full of energy, very comfortable, in perfect health, does not feel tired, everything seems to be good and happy. Patients often appreciate and feel like they have talent, can overcome all difficulties, come up with many programs and plans and believe in their success.
Emotionally, there is an increase in emotions, teasing people around without paying attention to the surrounding circumstances, emotions are easily influenced, when they are happy they can become angry or agitated temporarily due to external causes are insignificant (usually, such causes do not agitate them that much).
Increased thinking speed is reflected in the continuous and rapid appearance of ideas. The patient talks a lot, talks continuously, until his voice becomes hoarse. Sentences are often incomplete due to lack of concentration, and sometimes broken sentences represent the rapid emergence of ideas that they cannot catch up with.
The tendency to increase activity, combined with high self-esteem and reduced critical abilities, causes patients to engage in activities with high risks of serious consequences such as investing in areas they do not know, spending money. money on unnecessary things.
Patients can increase sex drive, increase appetite, eat more, and not feel sleepy.
2. Symptoms of depressive episodes
In contrast to the manic phase, in the depressive phase, people with bipolar disorder will have negative thoughts and emotions.
The patient feels sad for no reason, nothing can make them feel better or happier. The patient often underestimates themselves and feels guilty. The way they look at the past, present, and future is gloomy. Sad. sadness, disbelief in the ability to heal. Feelings of suffering due to guilt, unresolved sadness, and feeling stuck with no way out often make the patient have suicidal thoughts. Loss of energy, loss of enthusiasm at work, body weakness Change in diet, loss of appetite, decreased appetite, sometimes not eating Change in sleep, difficulty falling asleep, falling asleep or waking up Process associations are slow, the patient thinks for a long time, responds slowly, has a reduced ability to concentrate and pay attention. Sexual activity is reduced, in women it may be accompanied by irregular menstruation or amenorrhea.; The patient feels sad for no reason, nothing can relieve or cheer them up; Patients often underestimate themselves and feel guilty; The view of the past, present, and future is gloomy; Sadness, disbelief in the ability to heal; Feelings of suffering due to guilt, unresolved sadness, and feeling stuck with no way out often make patients have suicidal thoughts.; Loss of energy, loss of enthusiasm at work, body weakness; Change in diet, loss of appetite, decreased appetite, sometimes stopping eating; Changes in sleep, difficulty falling asleep, falling asleep or waking up; The association process is slow, the patient thinks for a long time, responds slowly, and has reduced ability to concentrate and pay attention; Reduced sexual activity, in women, may be accompanied by irregular menstruation or amenorrhea.
Men and women are diagnosed with bipolar disorder in equal numbers. However, the main symptoms of the disorder may differ between the sexes. Men may have many manic episodes while women may have many depressive episodes. Men with bipolar disorder during the manic phase may increase their abuse of stimulants such as alcohol, beer, cigarettes, drugs...
Men with bipolar disorder are less likely than women to seek medical attention on their own. Therefore, the rate of men dying by suicide is higher than that of women.

Causes of bipolar disorder
Bipolar disorder is a common mental health disorder, but until now the illness remained a mystery to doctors and researchers. Medical researchers have not yet determined exactly what causes some people to develop bipolar disorder. Possible causes of bipolar disorder include:
1. Genetics and physiology
The risk is often highest for relatives of individuals with Bipolar II Disorder.; The risk is often highest for relatives of individuals with Bipolar II Disorder.
There may be genetic factors that influence the age of onset of Bipolar Disorders.; There may be genetic factors that influence the age of onset of Bipolar Disorders.
There is some research suggesting that an imbalance in neurotransmitters or hormones that affect the brain may play a role in the disorder.; There is some research suggesting that an imbalance in neurotransmitters or hormones that affect the brain may play a role in the disorder.
2. Environmental factors
Life events and environmental factors often trigger the first mood disorder. It is thought that the stress that accompanies the initial attack causes long-term changes in brain activity, affecting neurotransmitters, as well as nerve cell loss.
Living environment also impacts patients with bipolar disorder.

Types of bipolar disorder
1. Bipolar I affective disorder
Bipolar I disorder is characterized by manic episodes or alternating depressive episodes.
2. Bipolar II affective disorder
People with bipolar II disorder are characterized by episodes of depression alternating with hypomania
3. Bipolar III disorder
It is characterized by recurring depressive episodes that turn into mania when using drugs. There is also a family history of bipolar disorder.
Rapid cycling bipolar disorder is characterized by at least four episodes within a year.
Bipolar disorder with psychotic features: accompanied by symptoms of psychosis (loud voices, visual hallucinations...
Bipolar disorder with atypical features (Atypical features) with symptoms of eating too much and sleeping too much, early onset, young age, psychomotor retardation, and other psychological disorders. (2)

Risk of bipolar disorder
There is no clear cause of bipolar disorder, but only risk factors that may contribute to the disorder can be considered, perhaps the same social situation, but the individual may have the disorder. bipolar then, and the other not. Therefore, we are only right with this individual but not with another individual. A stressful situation or situation often increases the risk of causing symptoms of bipolar disorder. For example :
The breakdown of a relationship Physical, sexual or emotional abuse The death of a close family member or a loved one These types of life-changing events can trigger depressive episodes at any time in a person's life.; The breakdown of a relationship; Physical, sexual, or emotional abuse; Death of a close family member or loved one; These types of life-changing events can trigger depressive episodes at any time in a person's life.
Bipolar disorder can also be triggered by:
Physical illness Sleep disorders Overwhelming problems in daily life, such as money, work or relationship problems; Physical pathology; Sleep disorders; Overwhelming problems in daily life, such as money, work, or relationship problems

How to diagnose bipolar disorder?
Diagnosis of bipolar disorder is based on identifying symptoms of mania or hypomania as described above. However, this disease is easily confused with other psychological diseases, so patients need to go to medical facilities that specialize in depression to be examined.
To make an accurate diagnosis, the doctor will conduct a disease symptom check through clinical conversations, tests, combined with medical history or information from the patient or family members. Additionally, your doctor will rule out disorders caused by the use of psychoactive substances.
Medical history: The patient is asked by the doctor to check whether there are symptoms of fatigue, drowsiness or movement disorders. Accurately identify symptoms of depression accompanied by mania.; Medical history: The patient is asked by the doctor to check whether there are symptoms of fatigue, drowsiness or movement disorders. Accurately identify symptoms of depression accompanied by mania.
Clinical examination Mental status assessment: the patient talks to the psychiatrist about thoughts, feelings and habits. If the patient allows, the doctor will ask family members and close friends of the patient about the patient's symptoms to provide more information for diagnosis.; Clinical examination Mental status assessment: the patient talks to the psychiatrist about thoughts, feelings and habits. If the patient allows, the doctor will ask family members and close friends of the patient about the patient's symptoms to provide additional information for diagnosis.
Mood chart: Doctors let patients record their mood every day with details such as mood, sleep, and body's emotional reactions to help diagnose and promptly treat bipolar disorder.; Mood chart: Doctors let patients record their mood every day with details such as mood, sleep, and physical emotional reactions to help diagnose and promptly treat bipolar disorder.
Diagnosis in children: Bipolar disorder in children is possible, although rare. The disorder is often diagnosed in older children and adolescents, but bipolar disorder can occur in children of any age. Just as in adults, bipolar disorder in children can cause mood swings from high levels of hyperactivity or euphoria (mania) to low levels of severe depression.; Diagnosis in children: Bipolar disorder in children is possible, although rare. The disorder is often diagnosed in older children and adolescents, but bipolar disorder can occur in children of any age. Just as in adults, bipolar disorder in children can cause mood swings from high levels of hyperactivity or euphoria (mania) to low levels of severe depression.

Treatment methods for bipolar affective disorder
Currently, doctors apply many methods to treat bipolar disorder. The most common of these are mood stabilization, antidepressants and psychotherapy. There are many medications used to treat bipolar disorder, but they are generally classified into two main groups
1. Mood stabilizers
Mood stabilizers Antipsychotics Antidepressants; Mood stabilizers; Antipsychotic drugs; Antidepressants
2. Psychotherapy
The method is carried out according to individualization of the patient. Doctors can choose monotherapy or multitherapy based on the characteristics of each specific patient. This helps maximize the effectiveness of treatment and improve the quality of life for patients. Psychotherapy is coordinated with medication treatment and maintained throughout the treatment process, to help patients understand more about the disease and themselves, adjust behavior and emotions, thereby managing the disease and reducing symptoms. effects caused by the disease. (3)

Prevent
It is difficult to prevent psychological disorders, but you can help yourself increase your strength when facing life's challenges.
Have a scientific diet with enough nutrients; Exercise regularly to improve mood and health; Have healthy relationships; Increase contact, chat with people, participate in social activities, group activities, and travel; Get enough sleep and don't abuse stimulants
Maintain a healthy lifestyle to overcome psychological disorders.

Related questions
1. Is bipolar disorder hereditary?
According to statistics, the proportion of people with bipolar disorder accounts for 1% of the world's population. The disease occurs in both sexes and the incidence of the disease does not differ between the two sexes. In particular, bipolar disorder has a genetic component. Individuals are at increased risk of developing the disorder when their biological parent has bipolar disorder.
2. Is bipolar disorder dangerous?
People with bipolar disorder will have many complex symptoms, and the fluctuations in mood greatly affect the patient's emotions and motivation for treatment. This is a disorder that changes the patient's psychology, affecting health, daily life activities, relationships as well as study and work performance.
For some individuals, hallucinations may appear, easily causing danger to the patient and those around them, so treatment is necessary and timely support is needed.

This is a disorder that changes the patient's psychology, affecting health, daily life activities, relationships as well as study and work performance.
For some individuals, hallucinations may appear, easily causing danger to the patient and those around them, so treatment is necessary and timely support is needed.

Related questions
1. Is bipolar disorder hereditary?
According to statistics, the proportion of people with bipolar disorder accounts for 1% of the world's population. The disease occurs in both sexes and the incidence of the disease does not differ between the two sexes. In particular, bipolar disorder has a genetic component. Individuals are at increased risk of developing the disorder when their biological parent has bipolar disorder.
